description: Dive into "Whispers of Romance in Nuremberg" ‚Äî a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Whispers of Romance in Nuremberg

places.generalDescription: Nestled in the heart of Nuremberg, the Sch√∂ner Brunnen, or Beautiful Fountain, is a stunning landmark that captures the essence of Gothic architecture. Erected between 1385 and 1396, this impressive structure stands at an awe-inspiring height of 19 meters and resembles a grand church spire. The fountain features four tiers adorned with intricate gilding and showcases 40 vibrant figures that embody various aspects of medieval life under the Holy Roman Empire.

sources.snippet: The citizens of Nuremberg, clearly, didn‚Äôt put much effort into naming the fountain, but I can‚Äôt argue with their logic: the fountain is indeed beautiful. But what‚Äôs more important is that it grants wishes ‚Äî all you need to do is turn a small brass ring on the fence three times. When you come up to the fountain, you‚Äôll see people lining up to turn it.
sources.shortName: 38 Things to Do in Nuremberg: a Local‚Äôs Guide

sources.snippet: Sch√∂ner Brunnen is one of the top things to see in Nuremberg. This ornate fountain dating back to the 14th century, the fountain contains 40 figures that represent the world view of the Holy Roman Empire. It stands 19 meters high and looks like a Gothic spire.
sources.siteName: The Planet D: Adventure Travel Blog
sources.shortName: Fantastic Things to do in Nuremberg, Germany

places.name: Sch√∂ner Brunnen

reviews.text: beautiful city. calm, clean, cozy. we walked after 6 pm, saw the sunset between the houses, enough cafes and pubs, people were resting, walking. want to come back again
Cool sculpture with ornate decoration.  Spire like so looks like it should be on. Cathedral!

Adorned fountain, lovely and small. Has a beautiful love story to the gate! (N√ºrnberg has so much history) don't forget to find the brass ring on the gate and spin it for luck! Even had an adorable  furry visitor to it  coming by for their own luck!

places.generalDescription: The Imperial Castle of Nuremberg, also known as Kaiserburg, is a majestic 11th-century castle complex that includes a royal palace and gardens. Perched on a sandstone cliff overlooking the city, it is divided into three parts: the imperial castle Kaiserburg, noble buildings in Burggrafenburg, and other structures to the east in stadtische Burganlage.

sources.snippet: Towering over the rooftops of Nuremberg, the Imperial Castle was once one of the most important fortified palaces of the Roman Empire. Explore the hidden staircases and marvel at the armour and weaponry, before taking a guided tour of the Sinwell Tower and Deep Well. At the foot of the castle are large boulders, perfect for little explorers to climb over.
sources.shortName: Nuremberg with kids: Top 10 things to do

sources.snippet: One of the first things to do in Nuremberg is to make your way to Nuremberg Castle. The Imperial Castle is the symbol of Nuremberg and has been standing since the middle ages dating back to 1050. Nuremberg played a significant role in the Holy Roman Empire and the castle symbolizes that power.
sources.siteName: The Planet D: Adventure Travel Blog
sources.shortName: Fantastic Things to do in Nuremberg, Germany

sources.snippet: If you are staying for the night and looking for excellent accommodation, book a room at the NH Collection Nuremberg City. The rooms here are comfortable and just a 5-minute walk from Nuremberg Central Station. The hotel also offers a gym, restaurant, bar, and fabulous breakfast.
sources.shortName: One day in Nuremberg, Germany

sources.snippet: Another 'must-see' in the city is the Palace of Justice, where the famous Nuremberg trials of the high-ranking Nazi officials were held as a result of the end of World War II. It‚Äôs about a half an hour‚Äôs walk from the city center and also very easy to reach with the underground.
sources.shortName: Best things to do in Nuremberg

places.name: Imperial Castle of Nuremberg

reviews.text: Visitors can explore the grounds and courtyards. A key highlight is climbing the Sinwell Tower for panoramic views of the city. The castle's architecture and exhibits effectively tell the story of its significance.

Every time, one can find something unseen before. For a quick ride or precise exploration of a certain part, it's a nice place. And, of course, the view from the top is stunning. Climbing the tower will praise you.

One of the most well kept castles for its size and age. Not a lot of English info so prepare to get the audio guide if you want to know more about the castle. Had fun climbing the tower and the views of Nuremberg were unmatched!

places.generalDescription: The German Railway Museum Nuremberg is a significant indoor-outdoor museum that showcases the history of rail transport in Germany. It was established in 1899 and features a wide collection of vintage trains, rolling stock, railway equipment, and artifacts from the 19th century to the present day. The museum provides an immersive experience for visitors to explore the technological advancements and historical events that shaped the modern train system.

sources.snippet: Transportation enthusiasts will enjoy visiting the Nuremberg Transport Museum (Verkehrsmuseum N√ºrnberg) which contains scale models of Deutsche Bahn‚Äôs, railway cars, locomotives and carriages. Nuremberg was home to the first German railway and the museum is one of the oldest in the country. Dating back to 1899 it was originally called the Bavarian Railway Museum.
sources.siteName: The Planet D: Adventure Travel Blog
sources.shortName: Fantastic Things to do in Nuremberg, Germany

sources.snippet: A must for all train enthusiasts, learn about the history of the German railroad at the oldest railway museum in the world. There are lots of fine models displayed behind glass, and restored and replica engines, all to admire from a distance with no touching. The lack of interaction was initially disappointing.
sources.shortName: Nuremberg with kids: Top 10 things to do

places.name: German Railway Museum Nuremberg

reviews.text:
A Must-Visit for Train Enthusiasts ‚Äì DB Museum Nuremberg Honest Review

I had a fantastic time exploring the **DB Museum in Nuremberg**, which offers a **rich history of German railways** and an engaging experience for all ages.

### **Location & Accessibility:** ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ
The museum is **centrally located** and easy to reach by public transport. It's just a short walk from **Nuremberg's main train station**, making it convenient for visitors.

### **Exhibits & Experience:** ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ
The museum covers **over 180 years of railway history**, featuring **original locomotives, interactive displays, and historical artifacts**. Some highlights include:
- **Beautifully restored vintage trains**, including steam engines and royal carriages.
- **A large model railway** showcasing railway operations in a fascinating way.
- **Interactive exhibits** explaining the evolution of railway technology.

### **Family & Kids-Friendly Features:** ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ
The **Kinder-Bahnland (Kids' Railway World)** is a fantastic area for children, with **hands-on activities and miniature trains** to keep them engaged.

### **Service & Facilities:** ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ
The museum is **well-maintained**, with **clear signage in German and English**. Staff members are friendly and knowledgeable. There's also a **small caf√© and a gift shop** with railway-themed souvenirs.

### **Overall Experience:** ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ
A **must-visit for train lovers**, history buffs, and families! Whether you're deeply interested in railway history or just looking for an engaging museum in Nuremberg, **the DB Museum is worth your time**.

Worth it üíØ!!!
It's really cool for train's fans. People can learn a lot about many kind of train in Germany. They also have break room (pausenraum oder Brotzeit Raum‚Äú.

We will come back again for sure.

Excellent railway museum, which lots to see. Allow at least 2 hours, but you can easily spend 3 hours here. Far more than just trains, as some really interesting models, historical exhibits and even an explanation about how train toilets work!
The App is worth downloading, as it gives additional information in English. Much of the museum has English captions.
Don't forget the separate shed and outside area across the road.

places.generalDescription: Handwerkerhof Nuremberg is a medieval-style shopping area located near the city walls and the railway station. It features small shops that specialize in traditional crafts, offering a unique experience reminiscent of the Middle Ages. Established in 1970 to commemorate Albrecht Durer's 500th birthday, this craftsmen's courtyard was initially intended to be temporary but has become a permanent attraction due to its popularity.

sources.snippet: It is a small area within the Old Town, close to the main train station, with lots of artisan‚Äôs shops and cute cafes. If you are looking for a souvenir, here you‚Äôll find Christmas ornaments, ceramics, leather, and wooden toys to name a few. Even if you are not up for shopping, Handwerkerhof is one of the prettiest corners of the Old Town with lots of Medieval houses and is a pleasure to explore.
sources.shortName: 38 Things to Do in Nuremberg: a Local‚Äôs Guide

sources.snippet: Another historic section in the Old Town is the Handwerkerhof Nuremberg. This artisan section is a Medieval village was a craftsman village that stands beside Nuremberg‚Äôs Old City Walls. Dating back to the 15th century this charming section of Nuremberg is a good place to enjoy a pint on an outdoor patio while watching artisans at work.
sources.siteName: The Planet D: Adventure Travel Blog
sources.shortName: Fantastic Things to do in Nuremberg, Germany

places.name: Handwerkerhof Nuremberg

reviews.text: Very nice small place which really gives you an insight on medieval times.

At the Nuremberg Handicraft Village, I had the chance to see beautifully crafted handmade items, including leather goods, candles, and clothing-all with a distinctly European charm. The atmosphere itself felt authentically European, making the experience even more enjoyable.

There are restaurants and caf√©s on-site, so keep that in mind if you plan to take a break during your visit. I was particularly impressed by the people there and received exceptionally friendly service.

However, the prices? Absolutely insane

I absolutely adore this place. It is literally the first thing you see after you exit the main train station and it is definitely worth your time. Plenty of tiny shops and cafes, you will most likely find something to peak your interest.

places.generalDescription: The Toy Museum, also known as Spielzeugmuseum, is a captivating cultural institution located in Nuremberg, Germany. Established in 1971, it offers a delightful journey through the history of toys with its diverse collection from various periods and cultures. The museum serves as an educational resource and nostalgic trip for visitors of all ages.

sources.snippet: The cultural history of toys is showcased through a vast collection of 85 000 objects at the Nuremberg‚Äôs Toy Museum (not all of them are on display). It may come as a surprise, but Nuremberg has a long history of being the center of toy making industry, dating back 600 years. Today, the largest toy exhibition in the world takes place here every year.
sources.shortName: Nuremberg Old Town: a Local‚Äôs Guide

sources.snippet: Nuremberg has a long history of toy making, starting with the doll makers of the Middle Ages. Marvelling at the historic toys behind glass, I couldn‚Äôt help but notice how delicate toys used to be, and how they wouldn‚Äôt last a second with my boys!. Thankfully there are designated play areas next to the entrance and on the third floor.
sources.shortName: Nuremberg with kids: Top 10 things to do

places.name: Toy Museum

reviews.text: We went to toy museum with our 3y old son, who totally enjoyed it. I enjoyed it a lot myself. We spent around 2.5h in total. There are 3 levels with all kind of toys. The last level is full of some games that was most fun. Price for adults is reasonable. while the boy didn't have to pay. Totally worth both money and time.

This museum is great. All kinds of toys make people go back to childhood. Although there are so many toys, there is actually no shop to sell them. I have to say that it protects parents' wallets very well. The children's play area on the third floor is also very good. I will come again.
I really liked this museum. It's a great activity for your next trip to Nurnberg.

places.generalDescription: Nuremberg's Historic Rock-Cut Cellars are a network of underground passages that date back to the 1400s. The cellars serve as a safe space during bombings and are packed with stories to discover. The tour agency F√∂rderverein N√ºrnberger Felseng√§nge e.V. provides guided tours of the labyrinthine passages.

sources.snippet: By far one of our favorite things to do in Nuremberg was to tour the N√ºrnberger Felseng√§nge. (Nuremberg Rock Passages) This labyrinth of underground tunnels dates back 600 years and was used to cool and store beer. Used by locals to seek shelter.
sources.siteName: The Planet D: Adventure Travel Blog
sources.shortName: Fantastic Things to do in Nuremberg, Germany

places.name: F√∂rderverein N√ºrnberger Felseng√§nge e.V.

reviews.text: It was very interesting to learn how the locals have built and expanded a vast tunnel network under the city and used it for different pragmatic purposes over the centuries. The guided tour was in German, but they hand out devices for different languages and the guide is competent enough to tell us the chapters to browse in each section he took us to.

Really cool tour. English speakers beware that you must rent the audio guide as the tour guide will only speak in German. It's a very interesting tour as the lighting and preservation was really well done. I ended up pushing more numbers on the audio guide and had more information than if I had only used the numbers the guide provided. I also had a small heart attack as I deviated for the group and I came across an Halloween prop of a woman covered in blood in a wheel chair with tape in her mouth in a very dark corner. Fun times.
The tour was super interesting and informative, our guide was funny and professional, I would definitely recommend it to anyone who is interested in the city's history.

places.generalDescription: Karl August - a Neighborhood Hotel is an elegant and modern hotel located in the center of Nurnberg. The minimalist yet stylish rooms are air-conditioned and offer free WiFi, with some featuring beautiful views from the terrace. The hotel also boasts a warm restaurant, spa area, and gym for guests to enjoy. Its convenient location places it close to several attractions such as Main Station Nuremberg, Spielzeugmuseum, and Goose Man Fountain.

sources.snippet: The Morgan & Mees Rotterdam is a boutique hotel near the vibrant Nieuwe Binnenweg. Housed in a stunning Bauhaus-style monument from 1938, the 20 rooms and suites, along with a penthouse, restaurant, bar, and terrace, represent an inspiring comfort amidst contemporary decor while being just moments away from the city's bustling heart.
sources.shortName: Best boutique hotels, B&B and romantic getaways Nuremberg

sources.snippet: A modern, upmarket hotel blending contemporary design with local craftsmanship in the heart of Nuremberg's historic old town. There's a Finnish sauna, a unique pool in the attic with views of the city from the long sky light windows, plus a chic on-site brasserie. A sleek and stylish getaway.
sources.shortName: Best places to stay in Nuremberg, Germany

places.name: Karl August - a Neighborhood Hotel

reviews.text:
I spent a weekend in Nuremberg and booked my stay at Hotel Karl August in the Old Town - and wow, what an incredible experience from start to finish.

I arrived at the hotel extremely early (check-in is at 3pm), but Leah at the front desk welcomed me warmly, took my bags, and even offered some great suggestions for places to visit in the meantime. When I came back around 5pm, I was greeted by Emilio, who upgraded my room and personally took my bags upstairs. He was incredibly friendly, and we got along great right away.

Shortly after settling into my room, I received a message on WhatsApp from reception asking if I was enjoying everything and if I needed anything - such a thoughtful and unexpected touch. I even shared some photos from my day with them, and the conversation stayed fun and friendly throughout my stay.

The facilities? Outstanding. The gym was spotless, stylish, and well-equipped - treadmills, a bike, rowing machine, high-tech smith machine, loads of water and towels - everything you'd want. The pool felt straight out of a Bond movie, sleek and modern with an epic city view. There's also a sauna, which I made full use of - a very cool extra.

The room itself was beautiful - comfortable, thoughtfully designed, and absolutely stunning from an architectural standpoint. Every corner of this place oozes style and class.

I can't speak for every hotel in Nuremberg, but I can say with full confidence that I had an amazing experience at Hotel Karl August. I'd absolutely recommend it and would love to stay again next time I'm in town.

Thank you, Vincent, Anna, Emilio, Leah, and the rest of the team - you guys nailed it.

We had a very pleasant stay. The room was clean, the bed was comfortable, and everything was well maintained. The staff were also very friendly and helpful.

Breakfast was generous and fresh. The location is ideal: quiet, yet within walking distance of the city center.

Extra highlights were the free use of the swimming pool and sauna, and the convenient underground parking just across the street.

Highly recommended!

Checked into Karl‚ÄØAugust for a quick city escape-what a delightful surprise. Sleek, modern lobby with that warm, friendly buzz you only get in a boutique spot. My room was compact but cleverly designed: big window, plush bedding, and a bathroom with just-right lighting and great pressure in the shower.

Staff felt genuinely welcoming-helpful tips about nearby coffee spots and even suggested a quieter local bar for later. Breakfast was simple but excellent: fresh pastries, tasty eggs, and strong coffee served in an inviting dining nook.

places.generalDescription: Cafe Bar Katz is a retro-hip cafe located in Nuremberg Old Town, offering a variety of soups, sandwiches, and bowls that change daily. In addition to artisanal coffee and cream cakes, they also serve alcoholic drinks. The cafe has a laid-back atmosphere with vintage interior and a sidewalk terrace where you can enjoy drinks like Aperol Spritz or wine while people-watching during the summer.

sources.snippet: They offer a small daily-changing variety of soups, sandwiches and bowls, as well as coffee, cakes, and a range of alcoholic drinks. It‚Äôs especially fun in summer, when you can sit outside and enjoy an Aperol Spritz or a glass of wine, while people-watching. It‚Äôs one of the few cafes in Nuremberg Old Town that‚Äôs open till 1 am.
sources.shortName: Nuremberg Old Town: a Local‚Äôs Guide

places.name: Cafe Bar Katz

reviews.text:
The food is extremely delicious.
With apricot jam, goat cheese, sesame leaves, and tomato they blend wonderfully together and is super cheap.
It is very crowded at night since people come for the food and atmosphere.
The food is served efficiently though.
Will surely want to try different dishes!
Cute little bar with mismatched furniture and eclectic decor. The food menu is small but creative. We enjoyed the pressed sandwiches we ordered!

The place is located close to downtown but in a really relax area, which I love because you don't get the noise of the city but in few steps you are in the heart of the city.
I would put this place more as a bistro than a pure coffee. The prices are fair and have space inside and outside for when the weather is nice. They have a selection of fresh home made cakes that are really nice with the correct amount of sweetness. Their beer menu is very good together with the cocktails, better than their coffee selection I must say.
The only downside for me is the kind of atmosphere, the deco is pretty retro chic cool but every time I am there I feel kind of uncomfortable because attracts an specific customer that makes me feel uncomfortable. But again, that is just me.

places.generalDescription: Ehekarussell, also known as the 'Marriage Merry-Go-Round,' is a controversial bronze fountain located near the White Tower in Nuremberg. Created by sculptor Jurgen Weber in 1984, this large and intriguing sculpture depicts various stages of courtship and marriage over six scenes, based on a poem by 16th-century poet Hans Sachs.

sources.snippet: The grotesque bronze fountain right by the Wei√üer Turm tower looks disturbing as it is, with half-naked men and women, bizarre animals, and skeletons strangling each other, but once you learn that the sculptures represent the stages of marriage, it becomes outright horrifying. Or funny, depends on how you look at it.
sources.shortName: 38 Things to Do in Nuremberg: a Local‚Äôs Guide

places.name: Ehekarussell

reviews.text:
Inside the medieval walls of the city, between past and present, the ‚ÄúMarriage-Merry-Go-Round" fountain  from 1984, created in 4 years by J√ºrgen Weber.
Inspired by the ironic  medieval poem of  Hans  Sachs  ‚ÄúDas bitters√º√üe ehlich Leben‚Äù, narrating the joys and sorrows of life as a couple that can be summed up in these stanzas : ‚ÄúShe is my virtue and my vice, She is my wound and also my plaster‚Äù.
One of the most fascinating fountains I've seen in a long time. Pitty not more info is displayed about its origin.

Walk around this beautiful bronze fountain to follow a couple's whole life, from the sweetness of first romance to the messiness of conflict, and finally, a haunting skeletal dance. The brutal honesty and brilliant level of detail make it a truly one-of-a-kind sight.

places.generalDescription: Wei√ügerbergasse, also known as Tanners Lane, is a picturesque street in Nuremberg that offers a glimpse into the city's medieval past. Lined with around twenty well-preserved half-timbered houses of various colors, it has been hailed as one of the best-preserved medieval streets in the area. Despite the heavy air raids during World War II, Wei√ügerbergasse survived unscathed, allowing visitors to admire these historic buildings in their original state.

sources.snippet: Wei√ügerbergasse is probably the most romantic and fairy-tale-like street in the city. Casually strolling here in the morning with a cup of coffee in hand is one of my favorite things to do in Nuremberg. Here you will find a string of colorful half-timbered houses that used to belong to leather makers but were later turned into cafes and boutique shops.
sources.shortName: 38 Things to Do in Nuremberg: a Local‚Äôs Guide

sources.snippet: Wei√ügerbergasse is one of the most popular areas with several very popular pubs. Mach 1, a disco, is very well known, for example.
sources.shortName: Best things to do in Nuremberg

places.name: Wei√ügerbergasse

reviews.text: A very typical street showcasing classic German architecture, very photogenic and beautiful. The day I visited, it was empty, but I'm not sure how it is on other dates. It's definitely a great spot to take photos and videos.

Wei√ügerbergasse is an photogenic tourist street in Nuremburg just north of Maxplatz. What you find here are nearly 20 half-timbered houses which date back to the Medieval period. The houses have been well preserved and restored after WWII air raids.

A walk down Wei√ügerbergasse provides visitors a glimpse back into the Middle Ages with delightful houses on both sides of the cobblestone street. These would have been occupied by tanners in centuries past. These days you'll find restaurants, bars and galleries filling the houses along Wei√ügerbergasse.

Even if you are not in the mood for a meal or shoppings. A quick walk up Wei√ügerbergasse is well worth making time for during visits to Nuremburg.
It's beautiful.  Nice

places.generalDescription: Hausbrauerei Altstadthof - Rotbierst√ºberl- Brauerei und Whiskydestillerie is a charming brewery tavern located in the Nuremberg Old Town. It offers a selection of local red beer, whisky, and classic Franconian dishes in a rustic setting with a large terrace.

sources.snippet: One of the most amazing things about the Nuremberg Old Town is that a chain of rock-cut cellars runs underneath it. The cellars date back to the XIV century, when a law was passed that obliged every brewer to have his own cellar for fermentation and storing of the beer. The cellars not only survived to this day, but withstood the air raids during the WWII and served as a safe space for the citizens of the city during bombings.
sources.shortName: Nuremberg Old Town: a Local‚Äôs Guide

places.name: Hausbrauerei Altstadthof - Rotbierst√ºberl- Brauerei und Whiskydestillerie und Gastronomie

reviews.text:
Excellent place for team events!
We started with the escape room located in the cellar. It's quite spacious that 8 of us can all move freely inside and the temperature is also comfortable. The content is pretty interesting, we chose the one related to historical story and everyone was enjoyed. After passing the game, we got N√ºrnberg original red beer as reward. There was a staff staying with us, who gave us a detail review in the end, and of course if you need help you can raise your hand at any time.
After that we went to the bar for the dinner. Food and beer were very good, and we also tasted special season drink called ‚Äúwinter W√§rmer‚Äù.
Waitress were super friendly and nice.
We had a wonderful time there.

A great spot to enjoy authentic German beer!  I skipped the meal hours and just enjoyed a quiet moment with beer. I'm not exactly a beer expert, but tasting different kinds and noticing their subtle differences made me realize-this is what really good beer tastes like. Experiencing that in such a historically rich city made it even more special üç∫

Just stopped by for a beer during a day out. The place was busy with lots of tables reserved but the helpful staff said we could sit at one for our drinks as we explained that we would only be 30 minutes as our bus was leaving shortly. We wanted to try the local beer and it didn't disappoint. If we are in the area again we will definitely go back to eat and have some more of the excellent beer.

places.generalDescription: Romantik Hotel Gasthaus Rottner is a charming 37-room boutique hotel located in the peaceful district of Grossreuth, just outside the center of Nuremberg. The hotel offers a range of rooms, each uniquely designed with round bathrooms featuring heated stone floors. Guests can enjoy the tranquil countryside setting and relax in the beautiful hotel garden under the shade of lime trees.

sources.snippet: A family-run luxury hotel with two contrasting properties; the first is a historic timber framed guesthouse and second a contemporary hotel. Spacious rooms are simply designed in a county-house style. Enjoy Franconian specialities served in traditional surrounds.
sources.shortName: Best places to stay in Nuremberg, Germany

places.name: Romantik Hotel Gasthaus Rottner

reviews.text: We were invited to dinner here by a friend and it was an experience of our lifetime! Starting with the Lavender Sparkling Wine, the steak tartar small bite, and the foie gras parfait, then the amazing Venison saddle with perfectly prepared sides! All courses served with paired wines.  The service was exceptional.  I wish I could dine here every night!

Excellent hotel, just on the outskirts of Nuremberg. The staff is extremely friendly and polite. Breakfast is decent, and they also have a 1* Michelin rated restaurant which was amazing!

There is limited parking at the hotel, but there are other free parking options nearby.

Working on my computer and bugs decided to join me.  This can't be just a one room problem, so housekeeping has probably brought it up to management seeing it often. Owners probably don't want to pay to eradicate the pests, have fun sleeping with them...
